Inverting a matrix by row-reducing with respect to $I$

Not invertible $\iff$ $Ax = 0$ has non-trivial solutions; Columns are linearly dependent; $rref(A)$ row of $0$s

$AA^{-1} = A^{-1}A = I$ (not the general case, of course, for matrix multiplication)
$(AB)^{-1} = B^{-1}A^{-1}$
$AB = AC \iff B = C \land A$ invertible

Decomposing $A$ into two matrices $= LU$

$L(Ux) = b \iff Ly = b$ (solve for y)
$Ux = y$ (solve for x)

Very easy thanks to $U,L$ Gaussian forms
